module.p: leòr satiety, sufficiency, enough (sometimes leòir in older usage) is an indeclinable, feminine simple common noun. It behaves in many respects like a generic quantity noun expressing a sufficient quantity.

In traditional (perhaps nowadays mainly ‘literary’) usage, leòr functions like other generic quantity nouns, with the exception that it needs a possessive determiner as pre-specifier –
mo leòr feòla enough meat (for me), my fill of meat
an leòr de na h-ùbhlan enough of the apples (for them), their fill of the apples

cf. làn
complement, fill, sàth
fill, satiety, surfeit.

section.p:
On its own –
Dh’òl Raonaid a leòr. Rachel drank enough/her fill.
Tha ar leòr againn. We have enough.
An d’fhuair thu do leòr?
Did you get enough? 393

With a genitive modifier –
Dh’òl Raonaid a leòr uisge. Rachel drank enough water [ie. her fill of water].
Tha ar leòr chon againn. We have enough dogs.
Bha a leòr airgid aige.
He had enough money. td. 393
Fhuair mi mo leòr de dh’òrain a-raoir.
I got (more than) enough songs last night. td. 246 Note the (perhaps ‘literary, self-conscious’) use of ‘de’ here rather than plain genitive.
Dhìrich e gu bàrr a’ bhalla cloiche a bha timcheall an taighe agus thog e deilbh dhen a h-uile càil a chitheadh e tro na craobhan. [...] Nuair a bha a leòr de dheilbh aige, chaidh e gu doras an taighe agus bhuail e an clag.
He climbed to the top of the stone wall that surrounded the house and he took pictures of everything he could see through the trees. [...] When he had enough pictures, he went to the door of the house and rang the bell. td. 66 Note the (perhaps ‘literary, self-conscious’) use of ‘de’ here rather than plain genitive.

The preposition de with a definite noun –
Dh’òl Raonaid a leòr den fhìon. Rachel drank enough of the wine.
Cheannaich sinn ar leòr de do choin. We bought enough of your dogs.
Dh’itheadh iad a[n] leòr de’n t-suagaraid de mhin-eòrna agus geir, a bha air a bhith a’ bruich ann an clùd ann am poit le bùrn goileach an taic an teine airson sia uairean a thìde.
They would eat their fill of the gloop of barley meal and grease, that had been cooked in a cloth in a pot of boiling water beside the fire for six hours. td. 312–3

With a prepositional pronoun –
Dh’òl Raonaid a leòr dheth. Rachel drank her fill [ie. enough] of it.
Tha ar leòr againn dhiubh. We have enough of them.
“Tha amharas agam gum beil hearòin air bòrd. Bha a leòr dheth aig an fhear ud agus bha e dranndan mu dhèidhinn pocannan air falach fo làr cèaban a’ sgiobair.”
“I suspect that there is heroin on board. That man had plenty of it and he he was muttering about sacks hidden under the floor of the captain’s cabin.” td. 313

ul.li:
mo leòr mu enough [information/knowledge] about –
Tha Màiri a’ bruidhinn a leòr mu choin. Mary talks enough about dogs.

mo leòr ri (dhèanamh) enough to do –
Tha a leòr aice ri dhèanamh. She has enough to do.
Tha An Comunn Gaidhealach a’ bruidhinn air Seanaileir ùr a thaghadh a bhios os cionn obair a’ Chomuinn. [...] Cha b’ fhuilear do dhuine de ’n t-seòrsa so tomhas mhath de chumhachd a bhith aige. [...] Bhiodh a leòr aige ri dhèanamh an toiseach ag ath-nuadhachadh dreach a’ Chomuinn.
The Highland Society is talking about choosing a new General who will oversee the Society’s work. [...] A person of this kind would have to have a good measure of power. [...] He would initially have enough to do restructuring the Society. td. 105, ‘Air an Spiris’
Tha a leòr aice ri dhèanamh.
She has enough to do. 393

module.p:
gu leòr to sufficiency is a prepositional phrase that can be used to modify (and quantify) a preceding noun –
Dh’òl Raonaid fìon gu leòr. Rachel drank enough wine.
Tha coin gu leòr aig Màiri. Mary has enough dogs.
Nuair a phòs an dithis òg bha fealla-dhà gu leòr anns an taigh-chèilidh.
When the young couple married there was plenty of fun in the pub. td. 115
Cha tigeadh duine dhan taigh-fhaire gu beul na h-oidhche. Bha tìde gu leòr agam airson smaoineachadh.
No-one would come to the wake-house until dusk. I had plenty time to think. 19
“Gheibh thusa duaisean gu leòr fhathast, a ghràidh,” ars ise.
“You will get enough prizes soon, dear,” she said. td. 72

However, gu leòr cannot be used with a definite noun, in a partitive sense – Dh’òl Raonaid am fìon gu leòr for Rachel drank enough of the wine. Also, gu leòr is indeclinable in the modern language and hence cannot agree with the subject – Tha coin gu mo leòr agam for I have enough dogs.

section.p:
Examples from Gairm –
Ma rannsaicheas sinn air ais fada gu leòir chì sinn nach robh sgoilean anns an Oban gus an ochdamh linn deug. Bha an sgoil bheag a b’ fhaisge air anns a’ Chill Mhóir cóig mìle air falbh, agus tha e coltach gu robh an sgoil sin air an fheadhainn bu shine an Earra-Ghaidheal.
If we research back long enough we will see that there were no schools in Oban until the eighteenth century. The closest little school was in Kilmore five miles away, and it appears that that school was one of the oldest in Argyll. td. 363

module.p:
In modern Gaelic, gu leòr also functions as an (exocentric, ie. ‘headless’) generic quantity noun compound, perhaps as an abbreviated form of uiread gu leòr a sufficient quantity –
Tha gu·leòr uisge ann. There is enough water.
Fhuair i gu·leòr de na h-ùbhlan She got enough of the apples. Note the (self-consciously non-standard, and hence ignorable) use of the interpunct in gu·leòr here to make it clear that this is a special use as an exocentric noun compound rather than as a prepositional phrase.

section.p:
On its own –
Dh’òl Raonaid gu·leòr. Rachel drank enough.
Tha gu·leòr aig Màiri. Mary has enough.

With a genitive modifier –
Dh’òl Raonaid gu·leòr uisge. Rachel drank enough water.
Tha gu·leòr chon aig Màiri. Mary has enough dogs.
Bha gu leòr de dhaoine ainmeil san sgìre againne ri mo chuimhne fhìn, gun luaidh air na ginealaichean roimhe sin.
There were plenty famous people in our district in my own memory, to say nothing of the generations before that. td. 112 Note use of ‘de’ here rather than a plain genitive.

The preposition de with a definite noun –
Dh’òl Raonaid gu·leòr den fhìon. Rachel drank enough of the wine.
Tha gu·leòr de mo choin aig Màiri. Mary has enough of my dogs.

With a prepositional pronoun –
Dh’òl Raonaid gu·leòr dheth. Rachel drank enough of it.
Tha gu·leòr dhiubh aig Màiri. Mary has enough/plenty of them.
Bheireadh e a’ mhòr-chuid dhen iasg dha na bochdan, agus ann an 1927 bha gu leòr dhiubh san sgìre againne.
He would give most of the fish to the poor, and in 1927 there was enough of them in our district. td. 112

Also –
Tha Màiri a’ bruidhinn gu·leòr mu choin. Mary talks enough about dogs.
Tha gu·leòr aig Màiri ri dhèanamh. Mary has enough to do.
